title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Bangladesh before 1 January 2017?
preds: Down 5%. Wish I could withdraw from the ~50% of the EWP questions I'm forecasting considering the question criteria.
Source in Bangladesh has indicated ISIS targeting pastors, not hard to see them expanding targeting to churches
Down 5% to be closer to the consensus.

http://bangladeshchronicle.net/2016/08/bangladesh-ranked-6th-riskiest-country-to-do-business/ Country risk for doing business is not necessarily the same as that for mass killing episodes, but there is some overlap. The worst countries for doing business in the above assessment are Syria, Yemen and Libya, then surprisingly followed by India, then not unexpectedly Burundi, followed by Bangladesh as another surprise.  Despite the above, I'm reducing my forecast from 2% made on 01 July, because a total of 1000 doesn't seem at all likely.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.

(no change) Two links to help clarify things until either GJO or @EarlyWarningProject can provide more global clarification regarding the relevant time frame(s). First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode begins on 5 May 2016 and ends on 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to explain the unexplainable.)
(no change, no link sorry) US State Dept is allowing family members of diplomatic staff to leave Bangladesh because of the increasing violence.

(no change) Here is one link I've relied on to confirm that the EWP questions are for the full calendar year 2016: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244986 I interpret this as confirming that it is for a full calendar year (if not otherwise specified).
Inching up to 5 on continuing killings by non-state militants.
There is already one incident on July 1-2, 2016
Up 3% on sense/guess that arrests may not be having the hoped for effect.
Down from 4% last month for passage of time. There are reports of targeted but isolated killings nearly most weeks. However, these are very unlikely to add up to a mass killing.

15 Prior
«Militants have killed more than 30 people in Bangladesh since early last year. Among those targeted were atheist bloggers, liberal academics, gay rights campaigners, foreign aid workers, members of minority Muslim sects and other religious groups.»
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-bangladesh-violence-idUSKCN0Z12B5
The current begum has for a change taken to arresting people who are probably dangerous, rather than concentrating solely on her political opponents.  Should work.

Up 2%. Seems to be two issues (from a helicopter view). The government is rounding up some undesirables and it will improve the near term stability or it is a reflection of trying to improve things with low likelihood of helping.
Even for a volatile region, one thousand deaths in a single incident (or series of related incidents) is a fairly high threshold.

The government seems to be handling the situation.  There might be some fighting but it looks more like they will be small out bursts than anything large scale.  http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/12/world/asia/bangladesh-arrests-over-3000-to-halt-attacks.html?_r=0

Edging back up again. Standing by my earlier thought that "The warning signs remain in place but the government's apathetic response may be restraining the likelihood of more widespread violence," and adjusting accordingly now that Hasina's government has decided to shed its insouciance at last. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36507173
Up 3% on reports that 2500 were detained related to terrorist activity.

The New York Times reports today that "Bangladeshi authorities say they now believe they have identified the top leadership of the two groups responsible [for the spate of machete attacks and other killings since 2013], and that they are preparing to round them up" (link below). From the story, I get the impression that these groups are not large or organized enough to move quickly from these one-off attacks to larger-scale insurgency in response to a police crackdown. So, I am trimming my forecast to 4 percent on the expectation that this story, and the police version of the attacks' origins, is basically true, and the attempts to stop these attacks will prevent them from escalating soon to anything like mass killing. There are still other possible avenues to mass killing in Bangladesh, but this one appeared most likely in 2016, and the baseline risk is generally quite low everywhere. I will trim further if we don't see evidence of escalation in response to these efforts to halt these attacks and will re-raise the forecast if we do see that escalation. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/09/world/asia/bangladesh-killings-bloggers.html
Sectarian strife and Al Qaeda related activities.

Down from last month's 5% for passage of time. Highly unlikely, though small scale episodes do occur, hence not going lower with seven more months to go. http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/12-killed-as-violence-mars-bangladesh-local-body-polls/1/680233.html
"The latest deaths bring to over 110 the total number of people who have died in election-related violence in the three and a half months since the announcement of the election schedule. "

Dropping this one down to 2% from 8%.
Don't think I will go back to my earlier forecast of 1%, as I am now more sensitized to how things can go wrong in Bangladesh.

Changing my forecast in a big way, as escalation of targeted violence doesn't seem likely in the short term. Will be interested to see what happens during Ramadan but at the moment it appears that lone wolf killings will prove a greater threat than any coordinated attack.

I looked at past data since 2005. Not one year when either Left wing or Islamic extremism led to a number as high as 1000! Statistical data suggests a really low number. Ok, agreed ISIS is creating troubles, but at this point, it doesn't seem to be a very huge issue. Internal issues are still more dominant, but 1000 is a far shot. Starting at 2%

2016 is set to be the hottest year on record. As temperatures soar, anger rises in those inclined to violence and religious extremism. It's like they have a virus,  and then add a burning fever to it. And then,  add the promise of a heavenly vacation with more than 70 virgins.

Down 7%. Sporadic killings only. The warning signs remain in place but the government's apathetic response may be restraining the likelihood of more widespread violence. Still well above consensus but I may be looking too far into the future. Make of this what you will : http://qz.com/687719/rising-islamic-extremism-in-bangladesh-is-a-threat-to-india-and-beyond/

There have been a recent spate of killings related to freedom of speech, so I would not be surprised if there would be more to come in the near future. The Bangladeshi judiciary has been slow to prosecute the alleged killers in recent cases, which does not serve as a deterrent to future perpetrators.

Edging down below 2:1 as potential for a major incident doesn't yet match up with actual casualty rate. Biggest question in Bangladesh might be where the trouble is most likely to come from. Plenty of discussion about rise of Islamist terrorism (  http://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/transnational-links-political-vacuum-fuel-bangladeshis-turn-to-terrorism ) but even a Bali Bombing size incident would most likely leave us well short of target. Political violence appears more likely but that requires people-power, which may not happen if economy remains strong. Nevertheless: http://www.nationmultimedia.com/breakingnews/319-garment-factories-to-shut-down-in-Bangladesh-30286006.html
A country going backwards and anger is building. Not a tinderbox yet but suspect that it could be in the next few months. Will monitor carefully.

"We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians over a period of one year or less." Not sure why Bangladesh has been flagged as a high risk country knowing population is 98% Bengali and 88% Muslim where minorities have not been subject to attacks seen elsewhere. Unlikely event

Notwithstanding the presence of Islamic State and Al Qaeda, the level of violence hasn't come close to hitting the 1000 threshold in any prior years. At current rate, deaths won't even hit 100. No. http://news.siteintelgroup.com/blog/index.php/categories/jihad/entry/410-the-rising-tide-of-terror-in-bangladesh

Apart from Turkey and Pakistan getting into a foreign relations spat with Bangladesh, there has been no fallout from Nizami's execution so far. If a sudden unexpected death is to trigger some violence, there must be an immediate emotional reaction from the person's supporters, otherwise the chances of a later reaction decline exponentially. Also, am going to be inactive for the next several weeks. So I am taking this forecast down into single digits in advance of my initial plans. Moving to 8% from 15%.

Nudging up to 7 on technicals, specifically: https://larswericson.wordpress.com/2016/05/10/gitrep-9may16pm/ I'd probably have tossed the 100 before averaging and will continue to skew lower on the belief that many of the high forecasts on mass-killing questions where there isn't an obvious high-casualty conflict process already ongoing (e.g., Nigeria) reflect a misunderstanding of the definition and resolution criteria.

Following the discussion on this thread, am raising my forecast to be above consensus for the next few weeks, until the fallout from Nizami's execution settles down.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/224791 http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/world/asia/bangladesh-executed-motiur-rahman-nizami.html?_r=1
The execution of a prominent leader with wide following is one of few rare things that could tip Bangladesh. However, I don't think death count (if it happens) from the related violence will approach anywhere near 1000. Hence the low forecast. Will take this back down after a week or so, if there are no other developments.
Yes. Things are boiling down there.

Settling in at the average of the forecasters who've explained themselves. This is one of those cases where the mere asking of the question (and the choice of Bangladesh over, say, Indonesia) seems likely to provoke overconfidence re: the odds of a mass killing.
To control the recent Islamist killings, the Bangladesh Government might react (proact) and kill to maintain control of the country.

Maintaining forecast. Yet another targeted killing (that makes it three in one week), but I don't see these incidents developing into an organised wave.
http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/south-asia/muslim-sufi-leader-murdered-by-suspected-islamists-in-bangladesh/article8570258.ece

I'm taking the last EWP statistical risk assessment, 2.8 percent, and adding 2 percent for the risk of non-state mass killing, which is probably about twice the base rate for that process. I think it's possible that the targeted killings of supposed heretics and infidels we're seeing this year could total more than 100 in 2016, and eventually form part of a larger process that kills more than 1,000. I also recognize that this is unlikely, though, and even less likely that enough killings will happen in 2016 to make a clear call about the onset of an episode of mass killing at the start of next year. If those procedural aspects weren't involved and I were just trying to make a call about whether or not this process would eventually comprise a mass killing, I would set my forecast higher.
There will be big problems over there...

You might think, what with getting washed out to sea every year or so, Bangladesh already had plenty of problems.  However, for the last couple of decades, a couple of very unpleasant women ("The Battling Begums") and their affiliated political parties have occasionally erupted into killing sprees of impressive magnitude.  They pretty much take turns winning elections and murdering or torturing or incarcerating or otherwise inconveniencing the opposition.   I have long ago lost track of who's in charge at the moment--I think it's the Awami one, but don't bet on this--and the latest spasm, associated with the 2014 election, seems to have subsided. I don't think there are more elections set for this year, so everybody there can now relax and wait for the monsoon to sweep them away.

https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/04/bangladesh-authorities-fail-to-curb-brutal-killing-spree-as-lgbti-editor-hacked-to-death/
Might be a lead to mass killing but it still seems unlikely.

The only research I can do in the time I got shows that Bangladesh is a rather peaceful place. They got clashes, sometimes, sadly, followed by deaths - but it's not getting even to the level of US high schools.

Agree with @Khalid, but only more so.  This may surprise/shock some people, but mass killings are more likely to happen in some advanced European countries than in Bangladesh; at least as far as this year goes with ISIS still being active. Guess this perspective may not be on the Early Warning Project's radar!

The main problem in Bangladesh is the inability of the two major political parties to tolerate each other. Similar to many other third world countries, the government disregards or prosecutes the opposition. However, though political disagreements have led to violence at times, killings especially mass killings are highly unlikely. A more disturbing phenomenon is the targeted killing of selected persons (self proclaimed atheists, gays etc) in gruesome ways, but again these are still just scattered incidents and nowhere near mass killings.  Bangladesh is ethnically quite a homogeneous nation, so there are no large groups of "others" to target. The only real possibility of mass killings occurring would be if the present government pushes the opposition past breaking point, leading to widespread strikes and prolonged shut downs that could degenerate into violent clashes between supporters of political parties. If that happened, it's quite possible the army would take over, to the relief of most of the population, rather than permit lethal encounters to continue.
